results.title: Brumby: Horse Run Wild
results.creator_credit: Sky Visuals, Australian Screen Associates, ABC-TV (Australia), Discovery Channel and Gary Steer
results.brief_description: Horses were brought to Australia 200 years ago as servants and loyal friends. Having served faithfully in work and war, they were turned loose. They ran wild, were named “Brumby” and branded outlaws. This wild, beautiful and noble animal is a threat to the natural environment. Brumbies are mustered and shot from helicopters, and this film contains scenes of shootings. However, the greatest killer of brumbies is drought - but they are as wild as the land in which they live, and they have a strong instinct to survive. Narrated by Bryan Brown.

results.title: Brum to the rescue and other stories
results.brief_description: Brum is a miniature 1920’s style vintage car. Too small to travel on the roads, Brum prefers the safety of the footpaths and byways. Full of fun - and just a little bit naughty! - Brum’s curiosity leads him into all sorts of adventures as he journeys out into the big world. Meet Brum in the following four delightful episodes contained in this video: “Brum to the rescue” - Brum rescues a little girl from two bullying children. “Brum and the kite” - Learning to fly a kite leads Brum on a funny chase all over town. “Brum and the car breakers” - Brum breaks down in a rubbish dump, and is taken to the car breaker’s yard. “Brum at the Opera” - Brum accidentally finds his way on to the stage during an opera performance.

results.title: Brum goes to the seaside
results.brief_description: Four further adventures featuring Brum, the mischievous little car. The adventures include “Brum goes to the seaside”; “Brum and the little girl lost”; “Brum goes kart racing”; “Brum and the stiltwalker”.

results.title: Bruiser
results.creator_credit: Studio Canal+, Peter Grunwald, Ben Barenholtz and George A. Romero
results.brief_description: The premise of writer/director George A. Romero’s curious revenge fantasy has timid office worker Henry Creedlow (Jason Flemyng) wake up one day to discover that his face has become a featureless white mask. His new found anonymity gives him a surge of power as he proceeds to wreak revenge on anyone that has done him wrong in the past. Free of moral consequence, Henry finds himself spiralling into a murderous rampage as he attempts to regain some of the authority he lost when he was a disrespected office worker and cuckolded husband. As an examination of white male urban angst, Romero heavily plays the metaphor of the blank mask. This white featureless facade pointedly alludes to the alienated individual whose sense of self has been completely eroded by personal circumstances and general societal mores. Any overt reference to Georges Franju’s 1959 eerie horror classic “Eyes without a face” (which also featured an outcast character with a blank white mask as a face) remain conspicuously absent as Bruiser aims for more visceral thrills than it’s eloquent predecessor. Cast includes: Peter Stormare, Leslie Hope, Nina Garbiras.

results.title: Bruegel's people
results.creator_credit: Vox Productions and Robert W Gutteridge
results.brief_description: Presents the work of the Flemish painter Pieter Bruegel the Elder. Summarises the sources of the emotions, expressed on the faces of Bruegels people, pointing out the civil strife, tyranny, and religious repression prevalent in Flemish society of Bruegel’s time. Narrated by Raymond Wilcox.

results.title: Bruce McGuinness in Melbourne
results.brief_description: In the late 1960s and early 70s, the Black Power movement emerged from cities and suburbs around Australia. Activist, Koori leader and filmmaker Bruce McGuinness helped strengthen the intersection of activism and filmmaking with his politically charged Black Fire (1972).
results.description: In the late 1960s and early 70s, the Black Power movement emerged from cities and suburbs around Australia. It was “the most exciting and dynamic era in modern Indigenous history” according to historian and Aboriginal activist Professor Gary Foley, who gained widespread attention for protests during the period. Fellow activist, Koori leader and filmmaker Bruce McGuinness helped strengthen the intersection of activism and filmmaking with his politically charged Black Fire (1972).

results.title: Bruce Dawe
results.creator_credit: Film Australia, SBS-TV, Robin Hughes and Linda Kruger
results.brief_description:
Episode of Series “Australian biography”.
An intimate encounter with the extraordinary “poet of suburbia”, Bruce Dawe, whose ability to evoke the drama and beauty of everyday life has set him amongst the most accessible and highly regarded of Australian poets. His highly empathic style of writing stems from a staggered history of variant occupations, contact with those from a diversity of backgrounds and failed studies as he drifted through his early years with a skill for writing but little direction. Here his motivations and writing process as they have since stood are explored. He discusses his family history and early life, his fascinations and motivations and his view of his place in the poetry world of giving a voice to ordinary Australians. Through interviews with Dawe, footage of him reading his poetry and commentary on his life and writing this is a comprehensive personal insight into Bruce Dawe’s life and influences.

results.title: Bruce almighty
results.creator_credit: Universal Pictures, Spyglass Entertainment, Tom Shadyac and Jim Carrey
results.brief_description: Local tv reporter Bruce Nolan doesn’t think that the world is treating him fairly. Then, after the worst day ever, Bruce angrily rails against God for ruining his life and mismanaging the universe. So God responds and endows Bruce with all of his powers to see if he can do a better job. Cast includes Jim Carrey, Morgan Freeman, Jennifer Aniston, Philip Baker Hall, Catherine Bell.
